title.narrative: Integrated Emergency Response to Food Security and Livelihood for the Sagar Cyclone Affected Communities in Lughaya district, Awdal Region

description.narrative: Based on the findings of the Inter-Agency Humanitarian Assessments Report of 25 June 2018 (Draft), had reported Lughaya district with the total of 6,207 Households of which 4,771 (76.8%) of the HHs are affected. TASCO was allocated 10 villages under Lughaya town, but not listed in the inter-agency report. TASCO’s rapid assessment preliminary report of 11th July 2018, have stated that the locations of Idocadays and Maame are found same location, which Idocadays is the name of the village and Maame is the name of the well situating in the village itself. Therefore, TASCO’s preliminary assessment report addressed 10 locations namely (Lughaye town, Idocadays/Maame, Haydayta, Laancawaale, Geerisa, Farda-laguxidh, Xoog-faras, Sheed-dheer, Geb, Beeyo-Kulul). The assessment of TASCO was undertaken from 6th to 10th July 2018. The findings of the preliminary assessment focused most severely affected families and communities in the specific assessed 10 villages of Sagar Cyclone affected areas in Lughaya of Awdal region of Somaliland. The project response is aligned with the allocation summary of the SHF-funded response to Cyclone Sagar, addressing integrated activities, with which TASCO is to provide Food Security and Livelihood of four components of a) Cash for Work (CFW) to support the desalting of damaged irrigation canals, contour banding, rehabilitation of water catchments, b) Provision of agricultural inputs (appropriate seeds and tools) to cyclone affected farming households who need to replant to utilize delayed Gu season, c) Distribution of fishing kits to households that lost their gear due to the cyclone and d) Restocking of livestock. The project will be implemented over a period of 6 months in 10 villages and will address emergency response for total of 4,908 persons break downed Men 933, Women 1,276, Boys 1,227, and Girls 1,472. The project is in response of FSL is focusing the following components: (i) Increasing immediate access to food, contributing (IPC 3-4) relating to SO 1amp SO 2 of the humanitarian response plan 2018, which priority activities will address:- a) Provision of immediate access to food for severely affected Households 550HHs, activities include unconditional transfers. ii) Protecting and restoring livelihoods, related food and income sources among most severely affected individuals and households, contributing (IPC 2-4), relating to SO1, SO2. a) Provision of Cash for Work: Improve post-harvest practices through provision of certified quality seed, training, land preparation and irrigation support) - Rehabilitation of 30 Shallow wells in three specific locations of Geb, Fardo Laguxidh, and Sheeddheer, methods of rehabilitation is to support the desalting of damaged wells and those filled by sand dunes, 30 HHs, 4 x 30 wells = 120 Individuals. - Rehabilitation of 30 Farms one hectare per farm each 30HHs, laborers 14 x 30 farms = 420 Individuals. - Distribution of 180kg Seeds in Geb, Fardo laguxidh, and Sheeddheer villages for 30 farms and 30 HHs - Purchase of 30 water pumps for 30 severely affected farms and hundred miter pipes per farm 30 HHs. b) Provision of fishing kits to households that lost their gear due to the cyclone - Purchase of five Engines boats 15 HPs (Each boat will own cooperate families consists 5 HHs. - Purchasing 51 complete Fishing Nets with accessories 3 for each boat for fishing cooperative communities for 17 fishing boats 68 HHs in Lughaya town c) Provision of livestock (Restocking) for 75 HHs in three specific villages of Idocadays/Maame,, Haydayta and Beeyo-Kulul, which TASCO assessment prioritized most villages with the deaths of livestock, each family will receive 13 heads (Goats), each HHs will get one male sheep/goat. The project intervention will contribute to the Food Security Cluster, which has been prioritized on the basis of priorities of the assessments and the areas identified as the most severe acute food insecurity, because of the Sagar Cyclone.
